raw_text:
Steady job growth continues in US
 
 The US created fewer jobs than expected in December, but analysts said that the dip in hiring was not enough to derail the world's biggest economy.
 
 According to Labor Department figures, 157,000 new jobs were added last month. That took 2004's total to 2.2 million, the best showing in five years. Job creation was one of last year's main concerns for the US economy. While worries still remain, the conditions are set for steady growth in 2005, analysts said. The unemployment rate stayed at 5.4% in December, and about 200,000 jobs will need to be created each month if that figure is to drop.
 
 "It was a respectable report," said Michael Moran, analyst at Daiwa Securities.
 
 "Payroll growth in December was a little lighter than the consensus forecast, but we had upward revisions to the prior two months and an increase in manufacturing employment." "Manufacturing is a cyclical area of the economy and if it's showing job growth, it's a good indication that the economy is on a solid growth track." That means that the Federal Reserve is likely to continue its policy of raising interest rates. The Fed lifted borrowing costs five times last year to 2.25%, citing evidence the US economic recovery was becoming more robust.
 
 Job creation was one of last year's main concerns for the US economy, and proved to be a main topic of debate in the US presidential election. While demand for workers is far from booming, the conditions are set for steady growth. "Overall, compared to the previous year it looks great, it just keeps going stronger and stronger and I expect that to be the case" in 2005, said Kurt Karl, economist at Swiss Re in New York. Meanwhile, economists cautioned against reading too much into data from the Federal Reserve showing an unexpected $8.7bn drop in consumer debt in November. A fall in consumer spending, which makes up about two-thirds of all US economic activity, could help limit the extent of any future interest rate rises. But economists said there could be a number of reasons for a fall in the borrowing, which include credit cards and personal loans, while noting that such figures can vary on a month-to-month basis.
llama3.2:1b: The US created 157,000 new jobs in December, exceeding expectations by one month.
This brings the total job creation to 2.2 million, matching last year's record.
Analysts view this as steady growth and a positive sign for the economy, despite some concerns about labor market conditions.
The unemployment rate remains low at 5.4%, and job creation is expected to continue in 2005 if it drops below 200,000 per month.
The Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates again due to robust economic recovery, with economists predicting steady growth for the economy.
llama3.2:3b: US job growth slowed in December but remained steady overall.
157,000 new jobs were added, taking total employment to 2.2 million.
Analysts expect steady growth and interest rates to remain high due to robust manufacturing employment.
gemma2:2b: US job growth was slower than expected in December, adding 157,000 jobs.
Despite the slowdown, the economy continues to grow, with unemployment remaining at 5.4% and analysts predicting continued growth in 2005.
The Fed is likely to continue raising interest rates due to stronger economic conditions.

Economists caution against overinterpreting recent changes in consumer debt figures, attributing the decrease to various factors and emphasizing the need for continued monitoring of consumer spending trends.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Job growth slowed in December but analysts predict steady growth for 2005 due to high demand for workers and continued economic recovery.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The United States created fewer jobs than expected in December but maintained strong overall job growth.
Analysts predict steady 2005 economic growth despite concerns over the unemployment rate and future interest rates.
Job creation remains a key concern for the US economy, with forecasts indicating continued employment gains through 2005.
qwen2.5:3b: Steady job growth continues in US despite fewer jobs created in December.
Job creation reached 157,000 in December, bringing 2004's total to 2.2 million, the best showing in five years.
The unemployment rate remained at 5.4% and about 200,000 new jobs are needed each month for it to drop.
Analysts predict steady growth in 2005 due to manufacturing job growth and solid economic recovery.
Job creation was a key concern last year and remains so this year despite consumer debt dropping unexpectedly in November.
opencoder:1.5b: Steady job growth continues in US economy.
The US created fewer jobs than expected in December but analysts reported that the dip in hiring was not enough to derail the world's biggest economy.
According to Labor Department figures, 1.570,000 new jobs were added last month that took place in 2.200 million to achieve the best showing for five years.
Job creation was one of last year’s main concerns for the US economy and proved to be a topic of debate in the US presidential election while the conditions are set for steady growth in 2005.
Overall, compared to the previous year it looks great, it just keeps going stronger and stronger which shows steady growth in the economy.
Economists cautioned against reading too much into data from Federal Reserve showing an unexpected $8.7bn drop in consumer debt in November.
While such figures can vary on a month-to-month basis, a fall in consumer spending could limit the extent of any future interest rate rises.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: The US experienced steady job growth in December, with 157,000 new jobs added, bringing total unemployment to 5.4% and promising growth of over 200,000 jobs monthly.
Analysts noted a slightly weaker than expected payroll report but highlighted positive trends in manufacturing employment.
The Federal Reserve is likely raising rates five times to control borrowing costs up from $8.7 billion.
Overall, the US looks strong with economic recovery improving, though consumer spending may decline.
tinyllama:1.1b: A steady job growth continues in US with over 2 million new jobs added in 2004, according to Labor Department figures released last month.
Analysts have attributed the decent report to the resurgent economy and the job market's ability to accommodate employers while demanding workers.
While the unemployment rate remained at 5.4% in December, economists warn that the rate is likely to decrease if manufacturing employment doesn't show significant growth.
A rise in consumer debt in November was seen as a temporary factor that won't derail the economy.
Meanwhile, analysts warned that interest rates could potentially rise in 2005 if demand for workers continues to outstrip supply.
tinydolphin:1.1b: US economy crept forward with steady job growth, with job creation continuing to outpace the expected, according to Labor Department figures.
Analysts say the dip in hiring was not enough to derail the world's biggest economy, with 2004's total rising to 2.2 million jobs.
The unemployment rate remained at 5.4% in December, but about 200,000 positions needed to be created each month if that figure is to drop.
"It was a respectable report," said Michael Moran, analyst at Daiwa Securities.
"Payroll growth in December was a little lighter than the consensus forecast, but we had upward revisions to the prior two months and an increase in manufacturing employment."
Manufacturing is a cyclical area of the economy, and if it's showing job growth, it's a good indication that the economy is on a solid growth track.
That means the Federal Reserve is likely to continue its policy of raising interest rates.
The Fed lifted borrowing costs five times last year to 2.25%, citing evidence the US economic recovery was becoming more robust.
Overall, compared to the previous year it looks great, and I expect that to be the case in 2005, said Kurt Karl, economist at Swiss Re in New York.
Meanwhile, economists cautioned against reading too much into data from the Federal Reserve showing an unexpected $8.7bn drop in consumer debt in November.
A fall in consumer spending, which makes up about two-thirds of all US economic activity, could help limit the extent of any future interest rate rises.
But economists said there could be a number of reasons for a fall in consumer debt, including credit cards and personal loans.

While demand for workers is far from booming, the conditions are set for steady growth.
The Federal Reserve will continue to raise interest rates based on evidence that the US economic recovery is becoming more robust.
Job creation was a major topic of debate during the 2004 US presidential election.

Economists caution against reading too much into recent Federal Reserve data showing an unexpected $8.7bn drop in consumer debt in November, as a fall in consumer spending could limit future interest rate rises.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The US added 157,000 jobs in December, bringing the 2004 total to 2.2 million, the highest in five years.
While job creation was a major concern, analysts believe conditions are set for steady growth in 2005.
The unemployment rate remained at 5.4%, with 200,000 jobs needed monthly to lower it.
Despite slightly lower-than-expected job growth, upward revisions for previous months and manufacturing job gains indicate economic strength.
The Federal Reserve is expected to continue raising interest rates after five hikes in 2004.
Economists also noted a drop in consumer debt but cautioned against overinterpreting the data, as consumer spending remains a key factor in economic activity.
stablelm2:1.6b: The US saw steady job growth despite creating fewer jobs than expected in December, according to Labor Department figures which showed 2.2 million new jobs were added.
Analysts believe the conditions are set for steady growth, although worries still remain as the unemployment rate stays at 5.4%.
While demand for workers is not booming, the report proves encouraging for job creation.
The Federal Reserve will likely continue raising interest rates due to evidence of a more robust economic recovery.
This year's job growth was influenced by an increase in manufacturing employment.
Despite some concerns, economists caution against interpreting data too broadly as it can vary month-to-month.
granite3.1-dense:2b: In December 2004, the US added 157,000 new jobs, bringing the total to 2.2 million, marking five years' best job creation.
Analysts anticipate steady growth in 2005, with about 200,000 monthly job creations needed for further unemployment rate reduction.
Payroll growth was slightly lighter than forecasted, but manufacturing sector's job growth indicated a solid economic recovery.
The Federal Reserve is expected to maintain its interest-rate hiking policy due to this robust economic performance.
However, a $8.7 billion drop in consumer debt in November may limit future rate increases as reduced consumer spending (comprising about two-thirds of the US economy) could occur.
Economists cautioned against overinterpreting this debt decline, attributing it to various factors that can vary monthly.
Overall, job creation remains a key concern, but conditions support continued economic growth in 2005.
